overview: Nahum pronounces doom on Nineveh, the Assyrian capital that had repented under Jonah but returned to brutality. God's patience has limits, and justice will come.

verses.text: The LORD is good, a stronghold in the day of trouble; he knows those who take refuge in him.
The LORD is slow to anger and great in power, and the LORD will by no means clear the guilty.

passages.title: The Fall of Nineveh
passages.summary: A vivid description of Nineveh's coming destruction—the cruel city would fall and none would mourn her.

facts.text: Nineveh fell to Babylon in 612 BC, exactly as Nahum prophesied—so thoroughly destroyed it was lost until archaeologists found it in the 1800s.
Nahum prophesied about 150 years after Jonah. Nineveh's repentance didn't last.
Nahum's name means 'comfort'—this prophecy of enemy destruction brought comfort to oppressed Judah.

figures.name: Nahum
figures.description: A prophet who announced God's judgment on Assyria, the empire that had terrorized the ancient Near East.

videos.title: Nahum Overview
videos.description: The Bible Project explores God's judgment on Nineveh and comfort for His people.
